article:
'Specific granules' are secretory vesicles found exclusively in cells of the
immune system called granulocytes. They are also known as secondary granules.

It is sometimes described as applying specifically to neutrophils, and
sometimes the term is applied to other types of cells.

These granules store a mixture of cytotoxic molecules, including many enzymes
and antimicrobial peptides, that are released by a process called degranulation
following activation of the granulocyte by an immune stimulus.

Specific granules are also known as "secondary granules".
